metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Global Normalized Urban Land Areas Composite Index (NUACI) with 30m Resolution
metadata.description: This dataset is the Global Urban Land Areas Composite Index (NUACI) dataset from 1984 to 2020. NUACI is a novel remote sensing index proposed by Professor Xiaoping Liu and others from Sun Yat-sen University, which integrates multiple remote sensing indices such as NDVI, NDWI, NDBI, and the intensity of night-time light remote sensing. It can be used to indicate urban evolution. The higher the NUACI, the more likely the pixel is to be urban. This dataset by obtained by directly calculating the remote sensing index production using Landsat images from 1984 to 2020 in the GEE platform. The global urban land-use change detection dataset obtained by segmentation of this dataset has an overall year-to-year accuracy of more than 75%. This dataset can be used for global year-by-year urban land use detection, year-by-year urban new land use change detection and other scenarios.
metadata.instructions: File name: year-gridid.tif. Among them, year represents the year, and gridid is the grid ID. You can search for the corresponding range of each grid in the attached GRID.shp. Data can be read with softwares adapted for TIFF Images

literatureList.titleEn: High-spatiotemporal-resolution mapping of global urban change from 1985 to 2015.
literatureList.referenceEn: Liu, X., Huang, Y., & Xu, X., et al. (2020). High-spatiotemporal-resolution mapping of global urban change from 1985 to 2015. Nat Sustain, 3, 564–570. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41893-020-0521-x

projectList.titleEn: National Tibetan Plateau / Third Pole Environment Data Center

background: Many global environmental problems are associated with cities, whose residents currently account for more than 55% of the world population. This percentage is projected to increase to 68% by 2050. Urban area composition is highly dynamic; however, our understanding of how cities change in space and over time is limited by the lack of spatially and temporally comprehensive urban land cover data at a high resolution. The current understanding of urban growth is largely based on demographic (population) data rather than information describing the spatial and temporal patterns of urban land-cover change. At a global scale, satellite-based approaches are essential for mapping changes in urban extent, but higher-resolution satellite-derived global urban land-cover maps are available only for specific epochs, while annual global products have coarse spatial resolutions of 0.5 to 1.0 km. The result is that existing datasets lack the spatial and temporal resolutions needed to fully capture urban changes, especially in areas undergoing rapid growth, such as China and India.
research objective: High-resolution global maps of annual urban land coverage provide fundamental information of global environmental change and contribute to applications related to climate mitigation and urban planning for sustainable development. Here we map global annual urban dynamics from 1985 to 2015 at a 30 m resolution using numerous surface reflectance data from Landsat satellites. Looking ahead, using these maps in conjunction with integrated assessment models can facilitate greater understanding of the complex environmental impacts of urbanization and help urban planners avoid natural hazards; for example, by limiting new development in flood risk zones.
challenges: Considering the unequal distribution of Landsat observations across space and time and their uneven quality due to varying cloud cover, limited observations exist for earlier years (that is, before the 1990s) particularly over Africa and Middle Asia and throughout the global tropics, resulting in higher uncertainties of detected urban expansion and green recovery for these regions and years.
methods: To generate a consistent database of global annual urban dynamics (GAUD), we used Landsat imagery to map annual changes in urban extent at a 30 m resolution for the period 1985 to 2015 on the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform. First, we defined the extent of urbanized land between 1985 and 2015 by fusing four available global urban-extent maps with similar spatial resolutions for 1985 and 2015. We extracted cells from the two fusion maps that changed from non-urban in 1985 to urban in 2015. We then used an annual time series (1985–2015) of the normalized urban areas composite index (NUACI) to detect the year of urbanization and green recovery (vegetative regrowth or new plantings in built environments) for each pixel within this urbanized extent. Finally, we assessed the accuracy of all derived products over the past three decades.
findings: We find that global urban extent has expanded by 9,687 km² per year. This rate is four times greater than previous reputable estimates from worldwide individual cities, suggesting an unprecedented rate of global urbanization. The rate of urban expansion is notably faster than that of population growth, indicating that the urban land area already exceeds what is needed to sustain population growth.

Verification.Question: Can higher uncertainties in urban expansion detection occur due to limited Landsat observations before the 1990s?

Disjunctive.Question: Which remote sensing indices are most relevant for mapping urban land use (NDVI, NDWI, NDBI, or others)?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the main challenges associated with using satellite imagery for detecting urban expansion?
Where can the high-resolution global maps of urban dynamics from 1985 to 2015 be generated and analyzed?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to generate high-resolution maps of urban land coverage on a global scale?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used involves utilizing Landsat imagery to map annual changes in urban extent at a 30 m resolution for the period 1985 to 2015 on the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting high-resolution urban land-cover data across different geographic regions and time periods?
Example.Answer: A challenge in collecting high-resolution urban land-cover data is the unequal distribution of Landsat observations across space and time, with uneven quality due to varying cloud cover, particularly leading to higher uncertainties in regions like Africa, Middle Asia, and the global tropics during earlier years.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that could be used to assess annual urban dynamics over several decades?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used to assess annual urban dynamics is the global annual urban dynamics (GAUD) dataset, which maps urban extent changes at a 30 m resolution from 1985 to 2015 using Landsat satellite data on the GEE platform.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the normalized urban areas composite index (NUACI) used in urban land cover studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: integrates various indices such as NDVI, NDWI, NDBI, nighttime light intensity, indicates urban evolution, higher values suggest greater likelihood of being urban

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges associated with collecting high-resolution urban land cover data using satellite imagery?
Feature Specification.Answer: unequal distribution of Landsat observations, varying image quality due to cloud cover, limited observations for earlier years, higher uncertainties in detecting urban expansion and green recovery

Feature Specification.Question: What are the features of datasets derived from Landsat imagery for monitoring global urban dynamics?
Feature Specification.Answer: annual changes in urban extent, 30 m resolution, annual time series of the NUACI, consistent global annual urban dynamics data from 1985 to 2015

Quantification.Question: What is the spatial resolution of the high-resolution global maps of annual urban land coverage?
Over how many years does the global annual urban dynamics data span?
What is the annual rate of global urban extent expansion according to the findings?

Definition.Question: What is the 'normalized urban areas composite index (NUACI)' in the context of urban land cover data collection?
Definition.Answer: The normalized urban areas composite index (NUACI) is a novel remote sensing index that integrates various indices such as NDVI, NDWI, NDBI, and nighttime light intensity. It is used to indicate urban evolution, with higher values suggesting a higher likelihood of a pixel being urban.

Definition.Question: What are 'global annual urban dynamics (GAUD)' in terms of satellite-based urban mapping?
Definition.Answer: Global annual urban dynamics (GAUD) refer to the mapping of annual changes in urban extent at a fine spatial resolution (such as 30 meters) over a given period, using satellite imagery. This process involves detecting changes in urbanization and vegetative regrowth within defined urbanized extents.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when interpreting global urban dynamics from Landsat imagery, and how can these challenges impact the accuracy of urban land coverage data?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges such as the unequal distribution of Landsat observations across different regions and varying quality due to cloud cover can lead to higher uncertainties in detected urban expansion and green recovery, particularly in earlier years and regions like Africa and Middle Asia.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of various remote sensing indices like NDVI, NDWI, and NDBI contribute to the interpretation of urban land changes at a high spatial resolution?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of multiple remote sensing indices, such as NDVI, NDWI, and NDBI, into a composite index like NUACI provides a new method for indicating urban evolution, allowing for more precise detection of urban land changes at a high spatial resolution.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do the observed patterns of urban expansion exceeding population growth have for future urban planning and environmental sustainability?
Interpretation.Answer: The finding that urban expansion is occurring at a rate faster than population growth suggests that urban land area already exceeds what is needed for population sustenance, which could have significant implications for urban planning and environmental sustainability, including the need to manage land use more effectively to avoid natural hazards and promote sustainable development.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges of obtaining high-resolution global urban land cover data at a 30-meter resolution?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in obtaining high-resolution global urban land cover data at a 30-meter resolution include the unequal distribution of Landsat observations across space and time, varying quality due to cloud cover, and limited observations available for earlier years, particularly in regions like Africa, Middle Asia, and global tropics, resulting in higher uncertainties in urban expansion detection.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be a significant discrepancy between the rate of urban expansion and population growth?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There is a significant discrepancy between the rate of urban expansion and population growth because the urban land area has been expanding at a rate four times greater than previous estimates, suggesting that urbanization is occurring at an unprecedented rate and that the urban land area already exceeds what is needed to sustain population growth.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for high-resolution satellite data in understanding urban growth over existing demographic data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for high-resolution satellite data in understanding urban growth arises because demographic data primarily reflect population changes and do not capture the spatial and temporal patterns of urban land-cover change, which is vital for mapping urban extent changes, especially in rapidly growing areas like China and India.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using Landsat imagery on the Google Earth Engine platform for mapping annual urban dynamics at 30m resolution?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using Landsat imagery on the Google Earth Engine platform allows for the creation of high-resolution global maps of annual urban land coverage, providing fundamental information on global environmental change and contributing to climate mitigation and urban planning. However, challenges such as the unequal distribution of Landsat observations, varying cloud cover, and limited data for earlier years can result in higher uncertainties in detecting urban expansion, especially in regions like Africa, Middle Asia, and the global tropics.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of multiple remote sensing indices affect the detection of urban land-cover changes over time?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of multiple remote sensing indices, such as NDVI, NDWI, NDBI, and night-time light intensity, into a unified index like the normalized urban areas composite index (NUACI) can enhance the ability to detect urban land-cover changes over time. This approach enables the identification of urban evolution and green recovery with greater accuracy, providing insights into the rate and pattern of urbanization.

Causal Consequence.Question: What implications does the rapid rate of urban expansion have on the spatial and temporal resolution of urban land-cover datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The rapid rate of urban expansion, which has been found to be significantly faster than population growth, highlights the need for urban land-cover datasets with high spatial and temporal resolution. Existing datasets often lack the necessary resolution to capture these changes accurately, particularly in rapidly growing regions like China and India. Improved datasets can better inform urban planning and sustainable development efforts by accurately reflecting the extent of urbanization.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of generating high-resolution global maps of annual urban land coverage using Landsat imagery?
Goal Orientation.Answer: High-resolution global maps of annual urban land coverage provide fundamental information of global environmental change and contribute to applications related to climate mitigation and urban planning for sustainable development. Using these maps in conjunction with integrated assessment models can facilitate greater understanding of the complex environmental impacts of urbanization and help urban planners avoid natural hazards.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are employed to handle the challenges of cloud cover and limited Landsat observations when mapping annual urban dynamics at a high resolution?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Considering the challenges of cloud cover and limited observations, particularly before the 1990s, the approach involves using a combination of Landsat imagery and the Google Earth Engine platform to map annual changes in urban extent. The methodology adapts to these challenges by integrating various data sources and focusing on areas with sufficient data quality, thus managing uncertainties in regions with sparse data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the normalized urban areas composite index (NUACI) be utilized to detect changes in urban land cover over time?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: NUACI is used to detect changes in urban land cover by analyzing an annual time series from 1985 to 2015. This includes determining the year of urbanization and green recovery for each pixel within urbanized extents. The index combines multiple remote sensing indices to provide a comprehensive view of urban dynamics.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What is the step-by-step process for using satellite-based approaches to create high-resolution global maps of urban land coverage?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves using Landsat imagery on the Google Earth Engine platform to map urban changes at a 30 m resolution from 1985 to 2015. Initially, urbanized land extents are defined by fusing global urban-extent maps from 1985 and 2015. Cells that converted from non-urban to urban are extracted, and an annual series of NUACI is used to identify the specific year of urbanization and subsequent green recovery. Accuracy is then assessed over the past three decades to ensure reliability.

Enablement.Question: What advancements in satellite technology have enabled the mapping of global urban dynamics at a 30 m resolution?
Enablement.Answer: The use of Landsat satellites and their surface reflectance data has enabled the mapping of global urban dynamics at a 30 m resolution. This approach provides the spatial and temporal data necessary to track changes in urban areas annually.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multiple remote sensing indices enhance the detection of urbanization and green recovery?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multiple remote sensing indices, such as NDVI, NDWI, NDBI, and nightlight intensity, into a new index like the normalized urban areas composite index (NUACI) enhances the detection of urbanization and green recovery by providing a more comprehensive indication of urban land cover changes.

Expectation.Question: Why do datasets often lack the spatial and temporal resolutions needed to fully capture urban changes, especially in rapidly growing areas like China and India?
Expectation.Answer: The lack of spatial and temporal resolutions in datasets is often due to the unequal distribution of Landsat observations across space and time, along with their uneven quality due to varying cloud cover. This results in limited observations for earlier years, particularly before the 1990s, and in regions such as Africa, Middle Asia, and the global tropics, leading to higher uncertainties in detecting urban expansion and green recovery in these areas and years.

Expectation.Question: Why is it challenging to map global annual urban dynamics at a high resolution?
Expectation.Answer: Mapping global annual urban dynamics at a high resolution is challenging due to the need to integrate numerous surface reflectance data from Landsat satellites over many years. The task is further complicated by variations in data quality and availability, particularly in certain regions and for earlier time periods, which can affect the consistency and accuracy of the results.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be a discrepancy between the rate of urban expansion and population growth, as indicated by global urban extent datasets?
Expectation.Answer: The discrepancy between the rate of urban expansion and population growth can be attributed to the observation that urban land area is expanding faster than population growth. This indicates that urban development is not solely driven by demographic changes, and the urban land area exceeds what is needed to sustain population growth, suggesting other factors such as economic development, infrastructure expansion, or policy-driven urban planning might be contributing to this rapid urbanization.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the challenges posed by the unequal distribution of Landsat observations when collecting data for urban dynamics?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges are significant due to the uneven distribution of Landsat observations across different regions and times, particularly before the 1990s in areas like Africa and Middle Asia. This results in higher uncertainties in detecting urban expansion and green recovery for these regions and years.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using remote sensing indices such as NDVI, NDWI, NDBI, and nightlight intensity in assessing urban evolution?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of these remote sensing indices in combination, as seen in the development of the normalized urban areas composite index (NUACI), appears to be effective in indicating urban evolution, as they integrate multiple data sources to provide a comprehensive view of urban changes.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways do you think high-resolution global maps of urban land coverage at 30m resolution can impact urban planning and climate mitigation efforts?
Judgmental.Answer: High-resolution maps provide fundamental information on global environmental changes, facilitating an understanding of the complex impacts of urbanization. This can help urban planners make informed decisions to avoid natural hazards, such as limiting development in flood risk zones, and contribute to sustainable development and climate mitigation efforts.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced when collecting high-resolution urban land cover data over large temporal spans.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the unequal distribution of Landsat observations across space and time, uneven quality due to cloud cover, and limited observations for earlier years, particularly in regions like Africa and Middle Asia, leading to higher uncertainties in urban expansion detection.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how remote sensing indices are integrated into a dataset to indicate urban evolution.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing indices such as NDVI, NDWI, NDBI, and night light intensity are integrated into the normalized urban areas composite index (NUACI), which is used to indicate urban evolution by combining these indices to provide a comprehensive measure of urbanization likelihood.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the challenges faced in collecting high-resolution global urban land coverage data and how they impact the accuracy of urban change detection.
Request/Directive.Answer: Considering the unequal distribution of Landsat observations across space and time and their uneven quality due to varying cloud cover, limited observations exist for earlier years (that is, before the 1990s) particularly over Africa and Middle Asia and throughout the global tropics, resulting in higher uncertainties of detected urban expansion and green recovery for these regions and years.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the methods used to generate a global annual urban dynamics map utilizing satellite imagery.
Request/Directive.Answer: To generate a consistent database of global annual urban dynamics (GAUD), we used Landsat imagery to map annual changes in urban extent at a 30 m resolution for the period 1985 to 2015 on the Google Earth Engine (GEE) platform. First, we defined the extent of urbanized land between 1985 and 2015 by fusing four available global urban-extent maps with similar spatial resolutions for 1985 and 2015. We extracted cells from the two fusion maps that changed from non-urban in 1985 to urban in 2015. We then used an annual time series (1985–2015) of the normalized urban areas composite index (NUACI) to detect the year of urbanization and green recovery (vegetative regrowth or new plantings in built environments) for each pixel within this urbanized extent. Finally, we assessed the accuracy of all derived products over the past three decades.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the implications of the findings regarding the rate of global urban expansion compared to population growth.
Request/Directive.Answer: We find that global urban extent has expanded by 9,687 km² per year. This rate is four times greater than previous reputable estimates from worldwide individual cities, suggesting an unprecedented rate of global urbanization. The rate of urban expansion is notably faster than that of population growth, indicating that the urban land area already exceeds what is needed to sustain population growth.
